moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6
comment: Offering a queen trade is unusual and I'm not so sure White should trade. But, it does cost Black castling priviliges and White has a lead in development, so it can't be terrible for White. The only question is whether a lead in development can be dangerous to Black if there aren't enough pawns to smother him or enough open lines to use a lead in development to good advantage.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4
comment: This prevents Black from developing ...Bf8-d6 where it would threaten Ph2 and prevent e4-e5. It also prevents ...Kd8-c7, which would help Black to connect his rooks on the back rank.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2
comment: White does her best to maintain perfect control of the d-file and to restrain Black from developing. In such a position every extra move White has to build an offense is crucial. Also, there aren't any seriously weak spots in White's position, so when Black gets developed he still won't have any immediate threats.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3
comment: Now White has a chance to use c3-c4 to control d5 and e4-e5 to chase Nf6 while creating a bind on Black, so that Bd7 and the rooks can't become active.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4
comment: threatening g4-g5; another way of chasing Nf6

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5
comment: Black steadfastly continues the plan to develop Bd7 and clear the d-file for his rooks. Apparently he wanted to play ...b6 and ...c5, so that when White played 12. a3 he couldn't see any good way to play Bb4 without it becoming trapped, so he traded it for Nc3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5
comment: Just a small tactical point: now Black can't avoid a weakened king-side because ...Ke7 can't defend both Bd7 and Nf6. Bxf6 would have to be met by ...gxf6.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6
comment: This is an interesting tactical attempt to avoid having to defend Pe4 and it had to have been in mind before she played f3-f4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6 Ke7 21. Ba6 Bxe4 22. Rhd1 Bc6 23. Bb7
comment: a third nifty tactic to force events. Getting rid of Bc6, so White can invade the seventh rank is more important than winning the exchange by Bxc8.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6 Ke7 21. Ba6 Bxe4 22. Rhd1 Bc6 23. Bb7 Be8 24. c4 Ba4 25. R6d3
comment: Apparently White needs to find (or create) another weak spot in Black's defenses, so it's not so easy for Black to defend.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6 Ke7 21. Ba6 Bxe4 22. Rhd1 Bc6 23. Bb7 Be8 24. c4 Ba4 25. R6d3 Bc6 26. Bxc6 Rxc6 27. Rd7+ Ke8 28. Bf6

1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6 Ke7 21. Ba6 Bxe4 22. Rhd1 Bc6 23. Bb7 Be8 24. c4 Ba4 25. R6d3 Bc6 26. Bxc6 Rxc6 27. Rd7+ Ke8 28. Bf6 Rcc8 29. Re7+
comment: White doubles rooks on the seventh rank because of this check. Black can't oppose rooks on the d-file.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6 Ke7 21. Ba6 Bxe4 22. Rhd1 Bc6 23. Bb7 Be8 24. c4 Ba4 25. R6d3 Bc6 26. Bxc6 Rxc6 27. Rd7+ Ke8 28. Bf6 Rcc8 29. Re7+ Kf8 30. Rdd7
comment: With both White rooks on the seventh rank Black is probably wishing he'd found some other move than 25...Bc6.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nxc6 dxc6 7. Qxd8+ Kxd8 8. Bf4 Bb4 9. O-O-O+ Ke7 10. f3 Rd8 11. Be2 Bd7 12. a3 Bxc3 13. Bd6+ Ke8 14. bxc3 b6 15. g4 c5 16. Bc7 Rdc8 17. Be5 Bc6 18. g5 Nh5 19. f4 g6 20. Rd6 Ke7 21. Ba6 Bxe4 22. Rhd1 Bc6 23. Bb7 Be8 24. c4 Ba4 25. R6d3 Bc6 26. Bxc6 Rxc6 27. Rd7+ Ke8 28. Bf6 Rcc8 29. Re7+ Kf8 30. Rdd7 Kg8 31. Rxf7 Rf8 32. Rxh7
comment: If 32...Nxf6 33. Rdg7# If 32...Rxf6 33. gxf6 Nxf6 34. Rdg7+ Kf8 35. Rf7+ Kg8 (else Nf6 is lost) 36. Rhg7+ Kh8 37. Rxg6 and Black's position is crumbling.
